title: Starting out
content:
> Here's what the plot looked like when I first got it in late March.

### Origin Story

Our great city, the city of Santa Clara, built an incredible park over what used to a holiday fair ground which was really a patch of ground that was used seasonally to hold a pumpkin patch and christmas trees. With this new park came a fantastic community garden with over 30 plots, outfitted with irrigation, tools, a composting bin, and even a beehive.

I applied back in early 2020 and got waitlisted, but for the next garden season term in 2021, I got it! Thus begins our journey.

title: A Garden is Born!
alt: A view of the garden after planting some stuff
content:
### Starting the garden for real

I had been sitting on the plot for a month... I was dealing with some stuff in my life so I didn't get a chance dedicate time to it. But I finally had an opportunity to prove myself at the Garden Cleanup Day, where I spent some time destroying the weeds around the garden.

I took the opportunity to run down to [Yamagami Garden Center](https://www.yamagamis.com) and picked up a nice haul! Lots of types of peppers and tomatoes, including:
- 2 ghost chili peppers (redundancy is key)
- 4 types of tomatoes
- Some herbs like basil, rosemary, and thyme to attract the nice bugs and keep the bad ones away
- And a few succulents for aesthetics

I kept some of the existing flowers which were in there; attracting more pollinators can't hurt.

I'm proud to finally *finally* get started!

title: A small desert garden
content: >Succulents and a few of the peppers we planted: ghost chili peppers, italian long peppers to name a few.

title: The other side of the plot
alt: The other side of the plot

title: #GardenGoals
content: >An impressive sunflower in another plot. This is peak gardening right here.

title: My first tomato!
content:
>My first tomato plant! I hope it doesn't get eaten.

I added some mulch to the plot to help keep the soil moist; the summer season is upon us and so is 90ยบ+ weather.

title: Succulents are growing up
content: >The succulents have started to push out of the ground.

title: The pepper plants are a little droopy
content: > I heard that underwatering peppers make them extra spicy. Is that true?

title: My first pepper is growing in strong!
This tomato plant is looking strong!
This tomato plant looking a little down :(
Not my flower, but it's very pretty!
I love the shape of this little guy
Planted some new succulents!
content:
Visited Half Moon Bay today and we always pass by these [greenhouse nurseries on Highway 92](https://goo.gl/maps/d7nUWz6sfLUCoYFe9). My sisters and I decided to give them a visit and we were not dissapointed! We found all these amazing succulents to add to our little desert garden. These look so cool!

Sadly, one of the succulents I originally planted didn't make it, so I removed it. Most likely because it was overwatered due to run off. RIP, little guy.

title: Pepper progress
content: Pretty awesome to see such a big pepper on such a tiny plant!

title: These tomatoes are starting to get their color.
Panic! My tomatoes are drying out!!
content: Ahhh!!! Some of my tomatoes are drying out, most likely due to the heat. It's hard to tell if it's because they are being over or under watered, but checking the soil dryness, most likely the latter. I'm going to see if I can increase their watering schedule and hope for the best!

title: Tomatoes getting their color
content: Sun gold cherry tomatoes. I think they are getting close to ripe! Too bad they are drying out :(.

title: This tomato plant could use some more water, I think?
